abstract.p: Ken Johnson reviews exhibition of 20th-century American art at Michael Rosenfeld Gallery; photos (M)

block.p: Organized to celebrate the Michael Rosenfeld Gallery's 10th anniversary, this densely populated show offers a fine hodgepodge of 20th-century American art. No particular criteria for inclusion are discernible: it looks as if the gallery simply took anything of interest out of storage and put it on view, letting the profusion of almost 60 works spill over into its offices.

The show boasts only a few first-rank names. There is a small but wild and rather goofy ''Dancing Head'' from the 1940's by Jackson Pollock and an unintentionally hokey, surrealistic mural design by Willem de Kooning, a nautical vision of the artist himself shirtless and in cut-off pants on a wharf with netting, rope, an oar and a sea gull that hovers like a divine portent.

Organized to celebrate the Michael Rosenfeld Gallery's 10th anniversary, this densely populated show offers a fine hodgepodge of 20th-century American art. No particular criteria for inclusion are discernible: it looks as if the gallery simply took anything of interest out of storage and put it on view, letting the profusion of almost 60 works spill over into its offices.

The show boasts only a few first-rank names. There is a small but wild and rather goofy ''Dancing Head'' from the 1940's by Jackson Pollock and an unintentionally hokey, surrealistic mural design by Willem de Kooning, a nautical vision of the artist himself shirtless and in cut-off pants on a wharf with netting, rope, an oar and a sea gull that hovers like a divine portent.

That most of the other works are by more marginal figures is a plus, however: this is not just another gathering of the usual, overexposed suspects. Among the more compelling works are, for example, a misty Magic Realist painting of an urn entangled by Christmas tree lights, painted in 1945 by the underappreciated Walter Murch; a diminutive vision of draped figures and a bizarre dog in a dreamy room by Dorothea Tanning that is all Surrealist cliches yet painted with an unusual sensitivity; and a semiabstract picture of swooping bulbous forms drawn and painted with rich physicality by the West Coast beatnik Jay DeFeo.

The show ranges freely across the spectrum of styles, from the old-time academic realism of a boy in a sideways hat tenderly modeled by Augusta Savage to the boogie-woogie Mondrianism of a grid painting by Charmion von Weigand. And such a broad and motley selection makes a good mirror for modern art, after all, reflecting as it does an invigorating diversity that Modernist theoreticians from Roger Fry to Clement Greenberg wanted to edit away.

Other highlights include one of the best Fairfield Porters you are ever likely to encounter, a small, radiant painting of a bouquet of buttercups; John Flannagan's fat, coiled snake, carved with rough, primitivistic craft from black sandstone; a zaftig, gilded dancer with dainty feet modeled in relief by Gaston Lachaise; a vibrantly colored, esoteric grid painting by the eccentric polymath Alfred Jensen; and one of Charles Seliger's spacey, fanatically detailed abstractions. There are dull spots, to be sure, but not enough to spoil the show.
